I had to write a critical response to Bill Blakemore's review of the Shining for college. It reveals a side of The Shining that few people notice. The Shining is about the Native Americans, and of course, America OVERLOOKING their genocide. There are many confirmations of this theory throughout the film, and after reading the review by Bill Blakemore, I can guarantee that you will want to watch The Shining again just to pick up on the motifs.

Read the review here:

http://www.geocities.com/fleta9/shiningreview.htm

title: Great horror film, maybe the best.
review: I thought that The Shining was a great horror film. It was probably the best horror film I had ever seen. It had really good casting for starters. Jack Nicholson was great in this movie (he's just naturally crazy, his wife's face is just creepy, perfect for a horror film, and that boy was pretty freaky too. The movie also had some really freaky music that kept the mood. If your going to make any movie based on a Stephen King book, its going to be pretty freaky. If anyone who is reading this has not seen the movie yet, I think you should read the book first. The book was better than the movie, but the movie still kicked.

title: Excellent movie!
review:
I really enjoyed this movie. The most interesting thing is its eerie atmosphere and the solitude feeling. It has a slow pace and it is quite long but this was necessary to create that atmosphere.

It has some really scary moments and leaves you with a mysterious mood. Be aware that some scenes are very haunting.

Applauses for Jack Nicholson and Shelley Duvall. Their performances were brilliant. I just felt very sad when Jack scolds his spouse when he was typing. I know he was going crazy but I think he was a little too CRUEL with her.

Recommended 100% for horror fans. This is one of those films that become a milestone for a genre.

title: I don't watch movies to get scared, anyway.
review:
Who cares if this is "scary" or not, in the traditional sense. If I wanted to get scared, I'd go ride my bike on the wrong side of the busy freeway. I'm in for a good story, or whatever you can absorb from a movie. And that, the movie had a lot to offer. I can't tell whether it's because we're not in 1980 anymore, or if it's about Kubrick's style, but I didn't get scared at all. But let's see: right from the beginning, you can tell what's going to happen. Every frame of the movie reveals there's evil stuff on the way. And when we reach the hotel, there's scary music being played *loudly* practically all the time. It's cool having dissonant classical movie being played on a horror movie, but it gets to the point of "okay, I GOT it already" eventually. And Jack Nicholson is freaky right from the beginning, anyway. There isn't exactly a crescendo of things going wrong; it's a crescendo of wrong things that have been wrong right from the start. And if I have to talk about a scary movie that isn't scary, I think I'd pick The Exorcist instead, and mention how that one *does* effectively create the growing sense of impending doom, that something that NEVER should happen will happen eventually.

The Shining, on the other hand, is too obvious all the time. The camera following the characters around huge halls and long corridors, as if something was about to jump out at them, followed by the aforementioned loud dissonant music, gives the impression of evil that just isn't there. It ends up feeling like Kubrick is pulling our leg, *pretending* the movie is scary when it isn't. But then again, it's supposed to be atmosphere, and it works when things start getting tense. The story, in essence, is very simple, but there are those strange, complicated twists along the way. I'm not going to tell the whole plot, since you can find it in almost every review here. Jack Torrance, suddenly, is transported to a 1921 party (as we can see by all the dancers on an *empty* hotel), drinks bourbon without being charged, and talks to a waiter that once was the caretaker of the hotel and killed his family before committing suicide. He is, clearly, being possessed by some kind of evil force that we can never discern, while his psychic son calls for help from Mr. Hallorann, who also has that power. Eventually, Jack chases his family with an axe, providing some exquisitely over-the-top performances, and all those ghosts and dead people start appearing. And after his wife and son manage to escape and he freezes to death, we learn that he *was* there before, in 1921. I don't find all that particularly confusing, since it's rather open to interpretation (I don't know whether that was the intention, but then again, I never read the novel). If *you* don't see sense on the story, you can find explanations out there.

To me, it isn't really about the story (I just don't like Stephen King), but the way it's treated. It's very masterfully shot and well executed. As the story progressed, I found myself captured by it, and that's what I want from a movie, really. The climax of the movie, while a bit disappointing considering all the build-up, was well made, with the chase in the hedge maze and Wendy seeing all those ghosts (including the guy in the costume with some fella who looked like George Bush). In particular, the moment when the blood pours out of the lifts was extremely well made, and the final result is very, very impressive - seeing that on wide screen, on the trailers, would have been utterly shocking. The performances, well, I can't praise them too much. I'm not sure whether I liked Jack Nicholson or not, but it certainly was a unique performance, and I don't doubt it inspired the hilariously awesome performance of Stefán Karl on the children's TV show LazyTown, even if only a little bit (I'm a Robbie Rotten fan). Shelley Duvall's constant whimpering and shrieking got on my nerves a bit, but it did look believable at times, and *thankfully* her character didn't fall on the famous "stupid victim" trap at any point. And Danny Lloyd was effective as young Danny (especially when you consider he DIDN'T KNOW he was making a horror movie, thanks to Kubrick's protectiveness). He didn't impress me - neither did Haley Joel Osment in The Sixth Sense, so maybe I'm not very interested in child actors, though I'm a stark raving fan of Jonah Bobo (Around The Bend, anyone?). So, who knows. I think this movie deserves to go down as a classic, since it's very unique, interesting and hard-hitting. It's BOUND to. And like every classic, it polarises opinions, and gets all sorts of passionate reactions. I won't add it to my list of favourite movies ever, but I wasn't disappointed by it, I don't regret watching it, and I'll definitely see it again if I can. For now, the aforementioned The Exorcist is in the top of my list. Maybe a Mike Oldfield soundtrack can give The Shining a boost? Everything is possible.

title: creepiest parts of movie
review: two of the creepiest moments in this movie is first when Wendy (shelley duvall) is looking for jack after their son is attacked and she comes upon his papers and typewriter and finds that he had not been typing a book at all but reams and reams of papers typed "all work and no play makes jack a dull boy", and the music builds and becomes more sinister when jack comes behind her and and she turns with the bat. creepy. the second is the ending when Wendy and the boy escapes and the music narrows and slowly zooms in the picture in the hallway and finally if focuses on jack in 1929 or 1921 whichever, and it is at the hotel!!!!! I was wondering if Jack had been reincarnated or what. But this movie is a classic on so many levels and it is just another Stephen King thriller that is such a classic.

title: Possibly one of the most terrifying rising actions ever put to film
review:
*******SPOILER ALERT******** Just got finished watching this film (a TV version that was being played on A&E) and I have to say that it has scared me in more ways than I can count. Well, at least the first half where Jack is slowly drifting off to insanity. I was terrified of the entire buildup because of how eerie it was, but the events surrounding the climax were not all that terrifying as I thought they would be (besides the part where Danny picks up the knife and is chanting 'redrum', I thought he was going to knife his mother!) However, the long take on Jack after being frozen the following morning in the hedge maze was really eerie and the gradual zoom up to Jack in the picture of the ballroom was probably the part that creeped me out the most. But, I felt the climax was not all that scary and just had your typical thriller qualities to it. However, I can easily see that Nicholson's portrayal of Jack Torrence's plunge into insanity is the reason why the film is on the list. Fantastic acting on his part.

All in all, an incredibly enjoyable film from someone who isn't even a huge fan of horror.

title: spoilers ahead
review: I've seen the film quite a few times and I still can't figure out how Jack got out of the food storage-room. I was locked in one as a practical joke and you can only be LET out. Mr.Grady surely is a ghost, so he can't have let him out. I don't get it. Also, what was Jack Torrance's character doing in a 4th of July, 1921 celebration photograph right at the end. Have I missed something or am I plain stupid? We know that Danny has some sort of sixth sense and Jack was a bit crazy so it makes sense that they'd see ghosts but Wendy? Had she also started seeing ghosts? She had an encounter with two engaged in a sexual act and also met that other creepy guy. Or is it the plain and simple answer that the place was already haunted. If so, why din't previous residents report sightings? Thanks.

title: Awesome Movie
review: I've never read the book although recently I've just begun to. I've read several comments from others that the mini-series is better. I've never seen the mini-series but considering the cast and the lead actor, are they out of their friggin' minds?! Jack Nicholson is one of the greatest actors alive. Steven Webber doesn't even hold a candle to Nicholson. I admit, Shelley Duvall isn't the best choice for Wendy, but she wasn't bad when the movie turned into the horror movie that it is. So what if the movie doesn't match the book and that they cut out a lot of stuff. If they left everything in, the movie would be like 5 hours long or something. Some people are just too picky.

title: Genuine fright-fest
review:
Defiantely one of the most frightening movies of all time. More than enough to scare the living daylights out of the more legitimate tough guy's.

Bringing Stephen King's novel to the big screen is definitely one of Stanley Kubrick's greatest achievements. And totally disagreeing with the 2 raspberry nominations. Oscar nominations is more accurate.

Jack Nicholson is remarkable for is transformation from being normal to becoming insane. Despite Shelley Duvall's razzie nomination, she did a good job with her expressions of terror. Even newcomer Danny Lloyd did a great job. Actually, all the acting was excellent.

The directing, the camera angles, the score, all successfully mixed together into a truly terrifying atmosphere. Excellent adaptation. If only Kubrick did this to other of King's novels before he died.

2001, Dr. Strangelove, the Shining, definitely makes Stanley Kubrick one of the best directors of his time.

title: Kubric's The Shining
review:
There's a reason why this film is dubbed "Stanley Kubric's The Shining".

It is not like the book. And mind you, both are very good. Just in different ways.

Kubric had a different view of Jack and his family, their stay in the hotel that winter, etc...and he brings that to the screen with chilling imagery, eerie subliminal flashes, and Jack Nicholson's performance as a wild-eyed madman.

That being said I enjoyed the film for what it is--Kubric's the Shining. Not King's the Shining.

The scenes were creepy, frightening, and unsettling. Blood pours out of elevators, The ghosts of twin girls tell Danny "come and play with us" as the images of them chopped to pieces flashes in front of our eyes.

Sure, it's not King's original vision--which of course is excellent!

But Kubric wanted to freak us out, give us the creeps, making us feel like we're watching someone else's nightmare. He's succeeded.

title: scared the *hit out of me!
review: This movie did and still does, scare the *hit out of me! I watched it for the first time when I was about 11 years old, by myself, in the dark and had nightmares for weeks after. Its one of few older horror movies that doesn't need fancy effects or digital ones to make it scary. And did that little boy truly scare the hell out of anyone else?! Good lord, he's almost as bad as that kid in the Omen! It is just flat out horrifying and no one plays a psycho like Jack Nicholson. I can't imagine anyone else filling this role so effectively. If you want to scare the crap out of a small child or even an adult, rent this movie, and make them watch it in the dark on a cold winter night by themselves. And please offer them a bathroom nearby.

title: "See? It's OK, he saw it on the television!"
review:
Personally I love this film, I think it's a great movie and stylistically brilliant. But I'm obviously not going to change anyone else's opinion on this film, so I won't try.

I'd just like to say that most of the people who seem to hate this film hate it because it doesn't follow the exact plot of Stephen King's book (which I have read and also like!) Well, it's an adaptation of the book not an unerringly faithful cover. It's Kubrick's version of the story- like a cover version of a song, and you'd probably feel a bit ripped off if the cover version was identical to the original, no? Other famous adaptations have changed source material- I mean The Godfather leaves out an entire subplot from Mario Puzo's book and I haven't seen anyone mark that film with one star because the source is changed! Approach the film without expecting to see exactly what is in the book and you might enjoy it a bit more. Make your own judgement on Kubrick's direction, but some of the tracking steadicam shots are undeniably great and the creepy visuals really get under your skin.

The one point I will concede to the 'haters'(sorry chaps can't think of a better word at the mo) is the ambiguity concerning Jack Torrance's character at the start of the movie. Is he already supposed to be crazy? He is a bit over the top to begin with.* In short, though I love this film i can understand why some people might not. I just don't think a good reason to hate it is because the source material has been altered.

*Not sure if this counts as a spoiler but I'm just covering my back!

title: Scary indeed
review: Well if the best criterion to rate a horror movie as good lies in its power to scare you I must say this movie is scary indeed. I won't exaggerate if I say this is maybe the greatest horror movie I ever saw. The horror here, if you overlook a few ominous ghostly apparitions in human shape some bleeding some not but always in broad light, lies more in the narrated situation developed through a series of scenes all of them well illuminated. As a matter of fact we don't have here the usual dark atmosphere nor lots of vampires, monsters or deformed ghosts. And if the haunted hotel house when seen from outside is sinister indeed all the interior scenes are filmed in broad light and the scenery is shown mostly in light colours contrasting with the omen always present almost from the beginning chiefly through the eyes of the little boy who has got supernatural knowledge powers. That makes it even more terrifying by creating the idea that it could happen to any of us. It's indeed the story of a nice normal couple with a beautiful young son that suddenly becomes a whirl of horror by the power of some hidden evil forces. I must confess I liked the performance of Shelley Duvall in the role of the frightened but courageous young mother better than Nicholson's. Though he is doubtless a great actor and has a good performance here, in the second part of the movie he is a bit too Grand Guignol for the general atmosphere of the movie with too many facial tics and grimaces. I wouldn't like to finish this comment without referring to the last scene of the chase of the boy in the snowy labyrinth which is thrilling indeed. Summing it up, it's an excellent movie with an excellent story (inspired in a Stephen King's novel), very well directed and with an excellent cast and an excellent scenery of interiors with inspired frames.

title: Great Movie...I think Not,A Magnum Opus, Yes, A Masterpiece, YES!!!
review:
You have never seen this movie you've lived a horrible, sheltered life (none-the-less seen any Stanley Kubrick films). Jack Nicholson, in possibly one of the greatest performances of all time, oohh, it just chills my spine how intense and crazed he seems to be.

Jack: "Wendy darling, the light of my life, I'm not gonna hurt ya-"

Wendyl: "Jack!"

Jack: "You didn't let me finish my sentence, I'm not gonna hurt ya, I'm just gonna bash your brains in": ect...

That is just a taste of the beauty. Stanley Kubrick's cinematographer rivals that of Martin Scorsese and Orson Wells. A beatiful soundtrack and visuals that still haven't been rivaled, AFTER 23 YEARS!!! Shelley Duvall puts up a sturdy performance, as long as with Danny Lloyd ("REDRUM!!"). Na dits always great to see Scatman Crothers. A clear work of art, that rivals every horror movie since "Frankenstein" (1931)!

title: Stanley Kubrick's The Shining
review:
A masterpiece of the Horror genre. I love this film.

Jack Nicholson stars as Jack Torrance, a writer who is applying for a job in the Colorado mountains and caretaking for th isolated, Overlook Hotel. He hears from the Hotel's manager that the caretaker of 1970 killed his wife and two little girls with an axe and then shot himself with a shotgun. Jack brings his wife Wendy and his son Danny with him. Danny has a psychic connection with the hotel's cook Dick Hallorann. Hallorann warns Danny about the hotel's past and tells him to stay out of Room 237. ONE MONTH LATER, Danny is having weird visions in his mind. Blood pouring out of an elevator. Two little girls stalking him. The mysterious word "redrum" on a door. Jack is having some weird experiences of his own. A ghost bartender has been selling him drinks for cash. Jack runs into the previous caretaker! He tells Jack to handle his family the same way that he handled his. Meanwhile, Danny tells Wendy that there was a crazy woman in the hotel. Wendy plans to leave the hotel on the snowmobile while Danny tries to contact Hallorann for help.

Jack Nicholson, Shelley Duvall, Danny Lloyd, Scatman Crothers, Barry Nelson, and Philip Stone star. Rating: 3 1/2 out of 4

title: Now without doubt a classic
review:
This is one of those films that age well. Very controversial in its time, I think it is now clearly a classic.

Should Nicholson have gotten an Oscar over DeNiro's performance in *Raging Bull*? No, obviously not--Nicholson is borderline hilarious in this, as is Shelley Duvall and for that matter even the great Anne Jackson (Scatman Crothers is, unambiguously, intentionally hilarious). But Kubrick's movies are not about "good" acting in the usual sense, and Nicholson's most over-the-top, eyebrow-popping, tongue-flicking, scenery-chewing mugging here works like a charm in a way it could not in any other movie because Kubrick was a complete original and a genius.

This movie simultaneously amuses, engrosses, terrifies AND alienates. I'm not here to say it's Kubrick's best movie, but it's certainly the one I've gone out of my way to see the most times so I suppose it's my favorite. It's not the scariest movie I've ever seen (that would be *Halloween,* and at least half a dozen movies rank above this one on that scale), but I defy anyone to genuinely watch this film with an open mind and not have the snot scared out of him/her at least 20 times. And it is certainly more artistically ambitious than all but two or three of the films I've seen that are scarier than this one.

I hope my review displaces the absolutely boneheaded one that was up on this movie's page when I checked it out (what exactly is a "prodding" screenplay?). This is not one of the 10 best movies I've ever seen, but it may be one of the 100 best, so it deserves more respect than it's getting on this site at the moment.

title: See the original
review: The people who edit movies for tv almost ruined this classic. In fact, the new tv version is totally stupid. This is one of my favorite films but you need to watch the unedited version to feel the depth of Jack's madness. For example, a maniac bent on murder does not scream, "you fouled up!" PULLLEASE!!

title: "Here's Johnny!!!"
review:
*** 1/2

Starring: Jack Nicholson, Wendy Duvall, and Scatman Crothers.

A writer, his wife, and his little boy decide to rent out a hotel with a very dark past. The hotel starts to change the father until he's nuts. The third act alone scared the hell out of me, and the rest of the film is frightening, too. I will say that Jack Nicholson is unbelievable as the lead.

title: The movie that defined the horror genre
review:
I saw this movie two years ago, but I can still remember that it scared the CRAP out of me. Granted, I usually scare easily, but not many movies truly terrify me the way this one did.

Being a huge fan of Stephen King's books and having seen almost all of the accompanying movies (The Stand and Shawshank Redemption are the only 2 that come to mind that I haven't viewed), I decided this was worth a look. Naturally, I read the book first and loved it. Now, normally, a book is better than its corresponding movie (which is the case with the majority of King's books), so I rented this movie with fairly low expectations. Boy, was I surprised at how well this movie was directed. The actors were amazing, the scenes were shot perfectly, and it was suspenseful in all the right places. To watch Jack Torrance slowly go insane is horrifying. This movie is true psychological horror; not just another "mindless slasher" movie.

*****MINOR SPOILERS***** The two most horrifying scenes in this movie, in my opinion, were the scene with the lady in the bathtub and the scene with the twins. No wonder Danny was so frightened; I'm 17 and that would scare ME (heck, it would probably scare ANY normal adult).

As I said in my summary, this is a movie that truly defines the "horror" genre. Suspense is present throughout nearly the entire movie, from the beginning to the terrifying conclusion. Kubrick did an excellent job directing this movie. The phrase "redrum, redrum" will forever be etched into my mind.

10/10

title: Absolutely terrifying
review:
The Shining is one of the scariest films ever made. It can't match up to The Exorcist but it comes a very close second. Jack Nicholson is great in this movie as the caretaker of the Overlook Hotel living with his wife (Shelley Duvall) and his five year-old son (Danny Lloyd). The son has a very special talent called the shining, which is something where you can see things that have happened in the past, that are happening in the present and that are going to happen in the future. He can see blood gushing out of lifts, ghosts of the old caretaker's two daughters and various other creepy things. Like the book, the caretaker becomes very isolated and shut-down from the world to a point where he tries to kill his family.

Stanley Kubrick does a good job in directing this masterpiece. He has other good movies but none like this one.

The Shining is a masterpiece of modern horror and see it as soon as you can.

title: HOW'D YOU LIKE SOME ICE CREAM, DOC?
review: THE SHINING is one of the creepiest horror films ever made. Though somewhat drawn out (made with near-perfection by perfectionist Kubrick), the film has eerie, atmospheric moments and great acting (though Duvall tends to hit a few of my nerves). Terrifying story of a legendary resort hotel that holds the spirits of its past in its present, and the family that caretakes it while it shuts down for the winter. This is one of my favorite Nicholson roles.

title: Not the first use of synthesizer
review:
Another comment said The Shining was the first movie in which a Moog synthesizer was used. Wrong! Look back nine years earlier to A Clockwork Orange. Electronic music for this movie also by Wendy Carlos, who, at the time was Walter Carlos. Don't know if this was the first either.

Okay movie. Creepy, but not scary. Too drawn out, too artistic. Kubrick is my favorite director, but the story is dull.

title: This Movie Was A Technical Breakthrough...A "Cinematic Masterpiece".
review:
The Shining was the very first movie to make extensive use of the Steady Cam, a camera attached to a special device which acts like a balancing beam that allows the cameraman to run and jump and make quick, jerky movements while filming, all while keeping a super-smooth shot. You will see the Steady Cam in action if you watch the "Making the Shining" if you bought a newer release of the movie.

Besides the introduction of new cinematic devices, the film also was the first ever to make use of the Moog Synthesizer. This electronic keyboard was used for the duration of the movie to produce it's eerie sounds. Did you think that the music in the movie was that of an orchestra? Well, it is not, as I found out in one of my physics classes. It was an electronic synthesizer capable of producing thousands of different sound effects. (All thanks to the musician Wendy Carlos who adapted composer Bela Bartok's original movements and performed them on the Moog synthesizer).

The Shining is probably best known for the blood spilling out of the elevators, which was most likely produced by building a small model of a room, and filming blood pouring out of the model at a high rate of speed. Thus, when the film is played back at normal speed, the action appears to be happening at normal speed, but is actually replaying at slow speed.

I love this movie because I praise it for being innovative and ground-breaking.

title: Care to Shine?
review:
I'm not sure whether I've come to admire Kubrick or not, but, in a bizarre way, I think you can't help but stand still and stare, while in awe, at a man of his artistic discipline and rigorous vision. Brilliant films such as the Clockwork Orange or Dr. Strangelove are undoubtedly tremendous achievements, Lolita remains an interesting experience, Full Metal Jacket put me in a strange mood, something between amusement and deep reflection (oh, well, maybe not so deep), Barry Lindon was just too awkward and long, despite showing off with some great costumes and art design, but The Shining...where can I put that?

After having read the story, I wouldn't really say that the book version was better, yet I don't have the conviction to affirm that the film is either. OK, so what it's about: a couple (the Torrance's) with one child travel to this lonesome, yet luxurious hotel somewhere in the mountains and get a job as caretakers, thus having to inhabit the hotel only by themselves for the winter period. All alone, desperate to put together a play, Jack Torrance takes a slip towards insanity...and it seems that being locked away with the same bunch of people over a long time frame can have quite devastating effects on the psyche.

SPOILER

I will just ask one question, which remains without answer from my perspective: why let Hallorren die after all that effort? It just doesn't fall into place and keeps me thoroughly unsatisfied. I wouldn't try to argue saying Stephen King's version of it was better, because it was too "soft and predictable", still Kubrick's choice leaves me puzzled.

END OF SPOILER

The film is truly entangled in its own weary life, wavering between its characters, delightfully portraying Jack Torrance's desperation. Nicholson is simply brilliant in doing it. On the other hand, Shelley Duvall is just a mess...she's so bad, I'd have normally expected her to ruin the whole movie. But this is the funny part: she didn't. Kubrick maintains some balance within the story and between the characters, although the ending kind of leaves me staring in a blur, due to it being somewhat meaningless, even absurd. It simply doesn't convey an acceptable solution, that's my issue.

On the whole, however, "The Shining" is definitely worthwhile, although not as impressive as Kubrick's other works. If you have any doubts whether watching the movie is productive or not, just imagine Jack Nicholson at his best. It's not the mysterious and terrifying King here, it's the pragmatic and analytical Kubrick.

title: A Classic...
review: Yes, before classic horror movies were destroyed into corny teen movies, there was a Classic. That Classic, my friends, was The Shining. I loved Jack Nicholson in this movie. Him and his character were somewhat related. He made you laugh, even though it was a horror movie. This movie is worth watching over and over again.

title: One of the greatest horror movies ever made
review:
Stanley Kubrick's "The Shining" is one of the greatest horror movies ever made. Sure, you could say it is not faithful enough to Stephen King's book, but it is still excellent. The fact that it isn't faithful to the book is actually somewhat of a good thing, because it makes it a work of its own.

"The Shining" has excellent build-up that is rarely seen in horror movies. Some complain that it is too slow, but really, it is perfect pacing. The problem that I see with most horror movies is that they try too hard to be scary at all times. In this film, however, every minute in the story is another piece added to the puzzle that will eventually become one of the most intense climaxes in the history of cinema. That isn't to say it is not scary until the climax. It is actually scary throughout most of the entire movie. The build-up is so strong, so suspenseful, that it makes it scary.

Stanley Kubrick's direction adds to the creepiness of the film. It is brilliant, to say the least. There are certain shots in this movie that are true cinematic masterpieces. Well, what did you expect from a legendary director such as Kubrick?

Shelley Duvall's acting is the worst part of the movie. Her acting is the main reason I didn't give this movie a 10 out of 10. Her acting sometimes ruins the disturbing atmosphere of the film. Jack Nicholson's acting is another story. His performance is as scary as they get. He has the power to make us really believe that he is a complete psycho, especially in the last half hour or so of the film.

So to sum it up, "The Shining" is a horror classic that delivers the goods.

title: **** out of ****
review: Kubrick's delve into horror succeeds in one level that most horror films fail on - it's actually scary.  Nicholson's performance is fantastic - yes, over the top, but perfectly fitted for the role.  This movie contains some of the most genuinely frightening scenes ever committed to film.  The common criticism is that Nicholson goes crazy to quickly, but it is a full hour into the film before he even begins to, let alone actually does.  This building anticipation towards the actual event is part of what makes this such a great horror film.  On top of all this, the film is technically masterful, with some of Kubrick's best camerawork, including some impressive long tracking shots.  Not just for horror either - there are lots of Kubrick themes and symbols woven into the story.

title: A well-crafted psychological tale of slow derangement
review: Like most of Kubrick's works, The Shining works on you after the initial viewing.  The sounds, the images, the dialog resonant  almost hauntingly in this case.  Many were disappointed by this film when I first saw it in 1980. But, such is the case with all of Kubrick's efforts after Dr. Strangelove. Upon further review and the required multiple viewings you find yourself humming the tunes, chuckling at many of Jack Nicholson's lines, and reveling at several of the film's brilliant images and steady-cam shots.  Nicholson and Shelly Duvall both give terrific performances.  Duvall's has been particularly underrated.  Try sustaining the sense of sheer vulnerable terror that she does throughout the second half of the film and you'll see what I mean.  The carefully selected music accompanying the film is among the best of any movie in history.  It is a crime that there is no `official' digital soundtrack available  though there are a couple of decent bootlegs out there if you look hard enough.  Those expecting to find the traditional horror flick in the vane of Stephen King's novel will be disappointed.  This is horror Stanley Kubrick style.  It is a well-crafted psychological tale of slow derangement, of helpless isolation, of the traces of the past that linger on to speak to those with the mind to listen  those who `shine' - whether they want to or not.  It's not the `boo' that scares you, it's the effective build-up and juxtaposition using all that the film medium provides to place the viewer inside a metaphysical construct.  Audiences aren't used to this approach to the horror film.  They are accustomed to surprise and in-your-face abruptness.  The Shining is more subtle.  And it lingers.  Much like all those things that have never escaped the lure of the Overlook Hotel itself.

title: Stranger In A Stranger Land
review:
Stanley Kubrick is my favorite director, and watching The Shining recently on DVD reminded me why. Kubrick has an uncanny way of setting up normal-looking objects and places so that they have an alien, spacey, distant quality. There are so many other adjectives one could use. He uses lighting, especially in The Shining, masterfully. The Shining, visually, is all about glows and indirect lighting, putting us in the mood for a ghostly story. Strange repeated geometric patterns, which Kubrick shoots with obsessive care, provide more mood, illustrating the relentless heartlessness of the icy world outside of the small bits of quivering, vulnerable warmth known as human beings. (The interlocking geometric carpeting which young Danny plays on, and the fabled hedge maze outside The Overlook Hotel are two prime examples of this.) Finally, even the camera work in The Shining contributes to its otherworldly, inhuman feel, as the camera flows down the hallways and around the corners of The Overlook like a ghost sweeping through a graveyard, or, even more relevantly, like the tidal wave of blood sluicing from the elevators in Danny's visions. The inhumanity in the way the camera moves - which is contrasted with the clumsiness of the human subjects the camera inevitably follows - causes the sneaking feeling that there is something "out there" which cannot be stopped.

Like the best horror films, The Shining works its fear by building dramatic tension. Jack Nicholson's performance explores all the rage, delusion, and confusion needed to lead us down the path from normal world to the other-world of The Shining's darkest moments. When he does go over the top, he plays right into the movie's hands. Even Scatman Crothers' jovial performance, seemingly at odds with the movie's tone, allows something Satanic beneath the surface. Shelly Duvall's Southern neurotic is somewhat unexplained, but she does her best, and visually she could not be more perfect as the dark-haired willow in the haunted hotel. Danny Lloyd as "Danny-Boy" holds his own in the surprisingly large number of scenes he is required to carry. His creepy 10-year-old voice screaming "Redrum!" as Shelly Duvall sleeps may give you chills.

title: red rum, red rum, geez! that'll NEVER leave me.
review: Stanley Kubrick is a movie making genius! I'll almost garuntee this movie will scare you in some way! POSSIBLE SPOILERS. Jack Nicholson plays the creepy father in a family of three who agree to take care of a luxerious hotel for the winter, a hotel in which is secretly haunted due to murders in the past. little does he or his wife know, their son has been blessed with something called "the shining", a power in which he is able to see things and contact people with his mind. As time goes on Jack Nicholson turns so twistedly phsycodic you won't ever forget his performance. And if his performance isn't enough, wait until the spooky ending...

title: scary
review: This was one of the scariest movies i've ever seen. Until towards the end when the family just fights. There were a whole bunch of scary parts if you just think about what's happening. This is about a family that are going to look over a haunted hotel. But they don't know it's haunted until later. They are all happy until things start happening. Jack (the dad) gets cabin fever and goes crazy. That's exactly what happened to the other people that looked over the hotel before Jack and his family This movie is not very gory but it is one of the scariest movies of all time. I think you should see this movie if you haven't.

title: The scariest movie ever made.
review:
A terrifying masterpiece. Stanley Kubrick in my mind (and it lots of others) is the best film maker to date. This movie is filled with great acting, very good eerie music, very haunting visuals and very disturbing images, it is truly a horror classic. Even though on the cover of the movie the Excorcist it says on the bottom the scariest movie of all time, i really don't think it is. I thought that also was a very good film, but the Shining was just fantastic. Anyone who is a fan of the horror genre and hasn't seen this go out and rent it tonight (all though i doubt anyone who is a big fan of horror hasn't seen it)

8/10

title: Kubrick's greatest horror movie of all times. Must see.
review:
Stanley Kubrick is well known in the world because of his masterpieces, movies like 2001 a space odyssey, A clockwork orange or Full Metal Jacket. But those are other movies, yet to be review by me. In this case I chose one of the best horror movies of all times, The Shining. This review will be divided in three parts you will see below.

PLOT: The plot is very Kubrick like. The novel has been written by Stephen King, a master of terror. Jack Torrance moves with his family to an old hotel to the be keeper for the winter. Everything looks perfect, until the father ( Jack ) turns into something like an imaginative alcoholic. The booze brought problems in the past, he hurt Danny (the son) in his shoulder while being drunk. Danny is a very important part of the film, he has supernatural habilities, even an imaginary friend named Tony. That's why he starts seeing strange things in the hotel. Then it all develops in the most scary movie I've ever seen. As you can see, the plot promises to be really freaky. But how does the viewer get scared?. We all know the low budget ( and sometimes high budget films ) with the monster and all the makeup, that doesn't really scare no one. That's why The Shining makes an art of visual effects.

VISUAL EFFECTS: Can you get scared if you see nothing? Depends on the screenplay. In this case, every single sentence is superb, all together make this script into a masterpiece. The creepy monster doesn't appear and we feel the fear in the air. The sutil appearances of the visions and phantoms make this movie better that any othe that spent millons of dollars on make-up. It all seems very natural. Something you will not regret: the pool of blood. That was probably one of teh high moments visual effects in this film. But how can we see the fear? It's in the faces, it's all in the faces.

PERFORMANCES: Jack Nicholson as Jack Torrance, psycho dad. Shelley Duvall as Winifred, Alias Wendy Torrance. And Danny Lloyd as the boy, the key to the whole drama. You can see in Nicholson's face he's really mad. The psycho part, really good. To express fear, we have Shelley Duvall. Later we would see her in The Portrait of a Lady. I can see in her face that she's really scared, and i trust her expression, because I really got scared. Danny is the mistery. He's boy in this case, and this is one of the few movies he made. But he acts very well. Danny, you have an A, and so does this movie. Peaz, out.

title: Magnificently Intense!!!
review: In my opinion this is one of Stanley Kubrick's greatest film, alongside A Clockwork Orange.  Not only because it follows a story-line that appeals to a mainstream audience, but also due to the intense, mind-blowing performance from Jack Nicholson.  The Man Was Nuts!!!  Kubrick films are always something special because you know each scene was probably filmed over fifty times before the director and actors were happy. As well I love the many tracking shots using the steadicam scattered throughout the film.  Plus the location the movie is shot at, genuinely creepy.  If you want a psychological horror film and not a slasher movie, check out The Shining.  (8 out of 10)

title: The #3 Definitive Horror Film (Spoiler?)
review: Stanley Kubrick's vision of the classic Stephen King novel has scared audiences for years and will do so for years to come. Most of the film takes place in a Colorado Hotel called "The Overlook." A man named Jack Torrence has been assigned the job of taking care of the hotel over the winter. He takes his family to the hotel and slowly, things begin to happen. The movie spirals into a creepiness not found it many films. The characters become believable and the story stays strong throughout most of the movie. I will have to say that the Video/DVD release is not my favorite version of this film. My favorite was aired on A&E. This version cut out the scene where Jack goes into a certain hotel room to see if a woman is in there that shouldn't be. I think the suspense of not knowing what's in the room makes the movie scarier. I have watched this movie several times, and I know I'll watch it again.

title: Aw, Shut Up Already
review: Listen: I don't really give a f**k if the movie doesn't follow the book, if the actors are all wrong (which you must surely be insane to suggest), if it's predictable or anything else, really - because this movie absolutely, completely terrified me. I'm talking "scared to death" here. No other movie has done that, ever. Therefore this is one of the best movies I've ever seen. Simple as that, really.

title: Absolute masterpiece and one of the greatest horror movies of all time
review: One of the greatest horror movies I've ever seen. One of the best films of Stanley Kubric as well. The landmark coldness of his style is very appropriate as we see the continuous alienation of the bitter loser heading to the insanity. Nicholson meticulously paces his part and equally perfectly depicts the slow transformation of the exhausted writer into the furious guard of the hotel's secrets and the emotional burst in the final. Vast spaces of the hotel halls, continuous use of the image of labyrinth act as additional personae of the story. Visuals in this picture are vivid and stunning.Unforgettable opening shot with flight over the northern landscape remains of a "Space Odyssey". Masterpiece!

title: Is the house haunted, or not?
review:
I feel that Kubrick was trying to make his audience wonder whether the hotel was haunted or, did the characters share some delusive dream?

Kubrick's films tend to build up, layer by layer, into a mounting avalanche that the characters cannot control. One miscalculation sets the avalanche tumbling down, taking on a personality of its own.

Stephen King tends to create battles between good and evil...The world is full of characters with either halos or horns..

Kubrick does not. He sees clashes of interest setting characters against one another and isn't trying to convince the audience to "like" or "hate" someone or something. The people we are at odds with in life have a view...and it's not all invalid.

Each time I view this film I see something I missed earlier. In my latest viewing the scene with Danny playing darts drew my attention. As he approaches the dart board a portrait suggesting a faceless woman is on the distant wall. As, he turns, he sees two small girls holding hands...In the background is another portrait...an extremely gruesome one of a woman on the distant wall...

When Danny is riding his big wheel down the hallways, he comes face to face with the two girls again...In the background is a window with drawn semi-transparent drapes...Behind those drapes is the figure of another woman looking on and slightly blurred..Second and third return takes then make the viewer feel that it was only a reflection of the hallway lights that created this vision...but a short rewind can create debate in a household quickly...The figure is more pronounced.

Kubrick was not trying to frighten his audience...just make them ponder.

Imagine some child in a mall....Mother just let go of a hand. Some kids panic while others run...Some feel abandonment while others feel a freedom to explore. King was the first of these while Kubrick cherished getting lost...Which are you?

title: Classic Horror Film
review: The Shining is one of my top 10 favorite horror films of all time for many reasons. One reason that is very clear is Jack Nicholson's performance as Jack. Stanley Kubrick (who happens to be one of my favorite directors) does a great job with making the movie scary as hell. Although many will complain that the movie is a lot different from Steven King's book (and it is) it is still a great movie and that shouldn't bring it down. The Shining is unlike most horror movies. It relies on images for frights and the formula works good. The blood in the elevator, the twins' ghosts, and all the different images of ghosts of the overlook hotel give the movie an intense feel. Overall The Shining keeps the viewer glued to the screen and delivers images and psychological thrills like no other. OVERALL: 10/10

title: A very, very long analyse of the film, from a person whose still learning English.
review:
Many people don't seem to understand that its impossible to compare King's novel with Stanley Kubrick's movie. In their own way, they are both psychological masterpieces. The problem is that they are so different one another that you can't say which is better. But there's something I have to say, and it is that they both scare the hell out.

A lot of people may think that Shelly Duvall's performance was clumsy, and they do, even Shining fans, but actually she deserved an Oscar for her acting and I'll tell you why. I liked this movie so much that I made a little research and I found out a logical explanation to everything that happens in this film. Wendy is hysterical, and I mean in the literal way. The Shining has something horrible that is that there is nowhere to hide. If your husband is trying to kill you, your son is epileptic and I'll tell you later why-, your salvation is a Negro who is dead, and your trapped miles away from civilization you would look like her to. And now she is a woman.

Wendy has lost the only person she could ever trust when Jack went crazy. His psychopathic from the moment his borne, but is only now that he really thinks that he is drunk, and that there people in the hotel. He hasn't drink any alcohol buy that sickness makes him think he has and know he is up to hurt his family.

After the bathroom scene, Wendy has suffer so much that she hysterical. She can't move, because she is so scared, but also she has to look for Danny, which is in danger. Compare Shelly performance with a normal hysterical person and you'll find no difference. She start to see things because of the trauma, she moves so weird because her sick body is paralysing her, but she also has to move. She is not a psychopath, but a neuropath. The bloods from the elevator, the skeletons, even Grady are obvious creations of her hurt mind, and she knows it, that's why she can continue her search for Danny.

The reason she sees something, is only because she is hysterical, and a hysteric woman exaggerate things, feels things, moves strange, and has a clumsy face. It's natural under the circumstances. You watch at Duvall, knowing what Kubrick wants out of her, and you scare the hell of because her expression of terror is so real not to say that she is ugly, and that helps, believe it or not- that you became and hysteric too, been scare of blood coming out of the elevator, when that is something funny under normal circumstances.

Danny. Danny is an epileptic, and the reason of the entire disaster at the Overlook Hotel, both the movie and the book, but in Kubrick point of view, everything you see is dicing to make you ask yourself `The ghosts are real, or are they all in their heads.' They can be in their heads. The phenomenon of Collective Hysteria is common, and examples of it are human waves. Someone starts it and the mind invents the rest.

The moment Tony which is a symbol of Danny's psychosis-, shows him a little example of what may happen if he goes to the hotel, a disaster starts and no one notice. Danny exaggerates thing, and goes to the hotel thinking he is going to find terror in there. He tells that to his mother, and she assimilates it deep in her mind. When he starts to see thing, his terror grows, so as his illusions. The Collective Hysteria presents because they are only three and their stuck alone for too much time.

By their own reasons, every one of them starts to think, even as a game, that there is people are ghosts with them that wish to hurt them. For Danny it starts when Tony talks to him at the bathroom, for Jack, when he imagines that his talking to Lloyd and drinking at the bar. This gets worse every time (the way Kubrick scares you) and then he believes he is actually drunken and wants to kill his family because they want to destroy him.

Until now, Danny divides his personality and his now Tony entirely. Wendy is obviously frighten because of that, and realizes that she is the last conscious person in the place. That is too much heavy for her, and that's where her problem begins.

After Here's Johnny, she is hysterical and then begins to watch things.

You see, The Shining has an explication in real life. But if you want to talk about the atmosphere, Kubrick is also the master behind this. The Overlook is too beautiful to be true, its decoration is perfect, and the white painting in every wall makes you thing that is extremely clean. But anyway, you'd rather been burn in oil before walking around all alone in those places, whether they are the rooms, the halls or the kitchen.

The contrast between white and the zigzag carpet makes an atmosphere that in no comfortable for the view already. Then, the sick full music starts to make you wonder what's going to happen. The contrast between beautiful scene, and terrible music is fantastic, and then, the actual terror.

It is not like in normal pictures, when you scare in one exact boo moment. Kubrick, for example, shows that killer and victim know exactly where they are each other and they even talk during a long time. When Wendy reads Jacks novel, her expression disturbs you, the music, the way she continues to look at the pages even thought she already knows they all say the same thing, and watching Jack from the behind, who is not dissimulating his presence; all that disturbs you, but when you mix them all, the terror goes beyond boo classical scenes.

In that particular scene, Kubrick could have simply make Jack appear from nowhere and start attacking Wendy, and that would have make people scream at the time. But no, the terror Kubrick used was psychological, and he shows Jack coming in a normal way, and announcing his presence before he even starts to play with Wendy.

The terror grows, and I remember I couldn't sleep for weeks because of the bathroom scene, and it still scares me because of Shelly's expression. This scene took the 127 shots before Stanley Kubrick considered it perfect. I'm sure Duvall hated him for a while, but in a time so did Malcolm McDowell. The death of Halloran represents not only the racism in America, but the idea that there's no place to hide at the Overlook Hotel, and if you thought that he was going to safe the day then you are mistaken. But the most terrifying scenes of the whole movie, believe or not, are the times when they tell you the day and situation. This is because it's a boo moment that means nothing, and makes you wonder in panic, but nothing really happens.

Slow motions makes things beautifully horrible, and the ending is satisfactory after the log waiting when you start to know that this characters love each other, but there's allways something to interfere with that like the wish to kill them all-.

The twins are just the scariest thing ever imagined, and that was another of Kubricks original ideas for the scrips. As I told you, the terror grows, and you see the twins for one second for the first time, for a minute the next, with horrible music later, and finally the both present themselves to Danny as the evil thing they are, and even better because after so much time behind Riding Danny the last thing you were expecting to find was two murdered sisters.

The reason this movie is so great, is still a complete mystery. But I think it is not one thin, but the mixture of thing, of giving the audience what they're expecting or not to, the music, the set, the slow motion, the one-second-long shots, the never-ending suspense or the masterful performances of Jack Nickolson, Shelly Duvall (God, I love her, even thought shes so ugly on that film) and, why the heck not?, Daniel Lloyd. He is the only really scary sick child, not like the Poltergeist's or even Haley Joel Osmend. They are good, buy Lloyd was the first scary child.

Stephen King hates this film, because it is not practically his book. It is weird that the movie is so different than the book, considering that A Clockwork Orange has a storyline practically exact to Anthony Burguess' novel. But you have to understand, and me being a Stephen King Fan, than a movie can't be exactly like the book, because that wouldn't be original, artistic, and several thing wouldn't have the visual impact a movie needs. The problem with the Shining, is that is too different. Carrie was half different, and it was perfect as a film, and still is a King film.

The Shining only takes some parts from the book, and the rest is the artistic vision of Kubrick. That isn't bad. In fact, that is very good, because it tells you that the writer of the script has an imagination of his own and for owing the right, he can even make fun of the original novel. If you don't understand this, then I'll put an example:

Chocolat is a fantastic film, and it is extremely different from the book. Five Oscar nominations, well deserved. Harry Potter, a copy from the book, a pathetic movie that has nothing artistic to offer, but the fantastic voyage of magic.

The Shining is a masterpiece in every way, and with The Others, the only movie that didn't let me sleep the night I watch it. I recommend it very much, but I can guarantee that you'll like it. It can get boring if you are not like me I like Barry Lyndon, may God help me- or like most of Kubrick's fans. But make your own opinion. I have mine.

title: The most horrifying horror movie of them all..
review:
The Shining is unrelenting in its effort to scare the living daylights out of its audience. Stanely Kubrick is ruthless in grabbing every frame, every scene, and every cue to keep hammering on the nerves of the audience. Not even a single moment is wasted on humor or sentiment. Stanley Kubrick is sincere in his aim to scare and scare he really does.

The plot is simple. Jack Torrence (Jack Nicholson) has to spend 5 months alone with his wife and young kid in a hotel in the lofty heights of Colarado.He has the job of looking after the place when it is closed for the winter. The hotel was built on an ancient Indian burial site and the previous caretaker went completely insane and after butchering his wife and two daughters, he put a shotgun to his mouth and shot himself.

This is one movie, which is extremely beautiful, yet scary at the same time. Kubrick's genius can be seen in almost every frame of the movie. The opening scenes, extremely beautiful give a wide panoramic view of the mountains, yet focus on a small subject like a lone car motoring along the mountains. This somehow manages to create a very lonely, eerie atmosphere. The hotel is extremely luxurious, brightly lit but is also very odd and eerie. Kubrick manages this by walls that are painted white and very eccentric carpets having intricate designs, which somehow offsets the balance of the place. White walls with orange carpets having a very zig zag design seem very odd. So is the feature of every room in the hotel. The kitchen also has the same kind of effect having a combination of white and pale green walls. Every room in the hotel has a luxurious yet distinctively uneasy appearance.

Kubrick just takes this and makes a movie that completely leaves you exhausted after 2 and half hours. Jack Nicholson is fantastic. Shelley Duvall although at first glance is seen miscast comes into her own in displaying the helplessness and hysteria in having to cope with her husbands insanity. The movie is a roller coaster hitting at the viewers nerves at every instant and works its way to the finale, which just leaves you a little flustered. Stanely Kubrick although explaining very detail leaves a few unanswered questions, which will be talked about as long as the movie is watched.

Altogether, 'The Shining' is one of the most scariest movie out there.....

title: Scariest movie ever.
review:
*The Shining*

I wasn't alive in 1980 so I don't know or care what people thought about this movie when it first came out. All I know is that the first time I saw this film it scared the heck out of me. What's scarier is that it still scares the heck out of me.

Everyone has a scene they found the most interesting or scariest. To me, it was the twins in the hall. To many people it was just Danny riding around on his bike, REDRUM, "Here's Johnny!", or the scary maze chase scene. All those things scared me. They still do. The end was also scary.

Jack Nicholson was fabulous, as expected. The young boy who played Danny was great. Is he still doing movies? Shelly Duvall... er... let's not go there. She just wasn't good.

If you like horrors, this is the ultimate.

*9/10*

title: What more could anyone ask for at 3am?
review:
When I first read the novel, I was 10 years old, and naive beyond all comparison. A year later I saw the film for the first time, alone at night.

I wondered until now as to why my little brothers had nightmares from just hearing the soundtrack from their bedrooms at the other end of the house. I was so stupid, that I thought that REDRUM was meant as in a RED ROOM. So much has changed. With the invention and distribution of DVD, I can now sit and watch this film in its UNCUT version (which has never been aired in Australian cinema), at 3 in the morning, and on a big screen, thanks to digital projectors. It was so terrifying to me (even though I know the "Shinning", of the Simpsons off by heart). The music was spine tingling, with a most frightening moment in the film actually being the cutscene, with the word TUESDAY. (The music built up to a climax, and was paid with many a scream) This is a masterpiece in almost every way. Jack Nicolson has always been scary looking, but this is undoubtedly the freakiest he has ever looked. I can almost go as far to say that he is the scariest monster in horror, and he barely spent 10 minutes in the make up room. The laugh of the old woman still haunts me, (and my little brothers) although not nearly as much as the Tricycle that Danny rides, and his many misadventures. Here is my question for anyone out there: What is the deal with the man dressed up as an animal. Was that in the uncut? Because I can't remember it. It was strange, completely off track, but frightening in its own way.

It also occurred to me, that the Hotel seems a lot scarier due to the 70's interior design. You may laugh at me, but room 237 was a lot scarier for me, due to the purple and green carpet. I strongly think that this film in its new and improved sense, has scared me. But really, if you want to let a child see this, even if they are tough, make sure that they understand what they are watching. For me it has made all the difference. Kubric did a great job. The film is so intense, that it has even made an episode of the Simpsons, and Rocko's Modern Life, quite chilling and freaky. I just wish that there were more horror films that were actually scary.

title: Probably the best made film to scare me
review:
"The Shining" is not the most frightening film ever made. For me, that honour belongs to the underrated cult film "Angel Heart." It is not the best horror film ever made, for me that is "The Exorcist." But "The Exorcist" cannot match this film for sheer psychological chills, and "Angel Heart" cannot match this film for sheer technical brilliance.

Stanley Kubrick is my favourite director (He should be everyone's favourite director) and his detatched, dehumanising style creates a kind of horror that is uniquely disturbing. For Kubrick, humanity is merciless and without compassion and, denied this for shelter, the audience has nowhere to hide. Most horror films spend time allowing us to bond with the characters, allow for comic relief, or create moments of human passion that remind us that no matter what happens we will always find comfort and protection somewhere in the human heart. That is not for Kubrick. Even before he goes insane, Nicholson's Jack Torrence is an isolated, cold and distant man, while his wife seems too preoccupied with controlling her own hysteria to demonstrate any compassion for her son. Danny's only friend is a spirit child named Tommy who talks to him through his little finger. The only man to show him a warm smile dies as soon as he returns to the hotel. The spare, clinical emptiness of the Overlook is a metaphor for Kubrick's style. Watching this film is like being trapped in a plain white room with a killer; there is nothing for us to dwell on but our fear.

Evil is never more terrifying than when conveyed by a cynic, and Kubrick is possibly the most cynical artist in human history. That is what makes "The Shining" so good.

title: In some aspects, this film is a classic
review:
O.k., this is one of those films where I can't point my finger at why it is so good. Don't try to find logic or common sense in this film, sometimes things just happened without an explanation. Nor even try to find a plot, there ain't much of one. The thing that stands out of this film is the acting and the way it is presented.

There were a few really well done scenes in the film and is used/sproofed by many other films. Sometimes the 'scary' music gets used once too many times and it does get alittle rediculous. The way the atmosphere and emotions created is excellent. The acting by Jack is outstanding, but I guess it is not surprising since he did star in "one flew over the cuckoo's nest".

title: one hell of a movie
review:
The Shining is one scary movie. But you will be more surprised and "suspensed" if you see it, haven't read the book, and if you do not know a THING about the story/movie. It happened to me, anyway! There I was, at the edge of my seat anticipating and expecting every move they're making will be freaky.

The great thing about this movie is that it makes you imagine all sorts of things and makes you expect "scary stuff". Anyway, Jack Nicholson one scary actor in this movie. He fits in his role like a glove, complete with his haunting eyebrows. Shelley Duvall, I must say is a great surprise. From watching too many Fairy Tale Theater, I didn't know she could look really scared!

Stanley Kubrick is a scary genius. And that's from only one view point since I have yet seen his other movies. We can never tell what goes on his mind... The Shining is a great movie, take you friends and family to watch this Classic and make sure to dim the lights.

title: Simply a great film, not just a horror flick
review: I really never get scared by movies, and saying about this film that "it's a really scary movie" seems to me demeaning and dippy.  This is not really a horror film, but an ingenious study of psychological archetypes.  I think it is a masterpiece, like pretty much everything that Kubrick has ever done. The direction is very original and very excellent.  Groundbreaking use of the steadicam makes the hotel itself a ubiquitous and omniscient character. It is amazing how Kubrick can work preexisting masterpieces of classical music into his films so well that they seem made for the film.  I have long regarded Bela Bartok as probably the greatest composer of this century, and Kubrick's extensive use of his "Music for Strings, Percussion, and Celesta" is incredible.  Nicholson's performance is perfect and bizarre, and every line is delivered so meaningfully and memorably.  Even seemingly unimportant lines like, "See, it's OK.  He saw it on the television." Like I said, I don't ever get scared by movies, and I consider this almost more a black comedy than a horror film.  I grin with delight throughout this film, sometimes bursting into laughter due to the intense wierdness of Kubrick's and Nicholson's flamboyant interpretation of the madman.  Memorable lines include "I swear I wouldn't touch one goddamn hair on his goddamn little head. I love the little sunuvabitch!!"  "'What'll it be sir?'  'Hair of the dog that bit me.'  Bourbon on the rocks!'  'That'll do it.'"  One more thing I have to add: rack zoom in on guy in dog suit kneeling down in front of a guy that looks like Charlton Heston as they both stare at Wendy. Awesome!

title: A masterpiece about the De-humanization of man
review: A Masterpeice about the De-humanization of man. This movie shows how isolation or "all work and no play" can turn a person psycho, and into a killer. This follows suit with a few of Kubricks other movies about the de-humanization of man: Full Metal Jacket, Spartacus, and A Clockwork Orange.

title: VERY scary movie
review:
"The Shining" is an impressive horror film from Stanley Kubrick. The story is about Jack Torrence (Jack Nicholson, in top form), his wife Wendy (Shelly Duvall), and their son Danny (Danny Lloyd) going up to the Overlook Hotel for the winter. However, Danny starts seeing things about the Overlook that present it as an evil place, while Jack is losing his mind from writer's block, and the evil forces in the hotel. As with every Stanley Kubrick film, it's thought-provoking (esp. the ending!). The scariest scenes in the film are:

*(Minor Spoilers)*

The twins at the end of the hall ("Come and play with us Danny...Forever...and ever...and ever), The woman in the bathtub, Danny's possession by "Tony"

The music is also haunting, and stays with you for a LONG time, as with many of Kubrick's films. While Shelly Duvall gets annoying at times, it's (in a way) necessary) Ranks up with the scariest movies of all time (Exorcist, Pet Sematary 1). See "The Shining" ASAP.

title: The Best Horror Film Ever Made
review:
I was watching this film again last night and I cant believe how it manages to scare me every time I watch.

I am a Fan of many Horror films but all of them seem to lose there impact on me after a few viewings and although I still enjoy to watch them again and again they don't scare me like this one does.

The scariest moments in the film involve the character of Danny like when he encounters the two girls in the hallway, the way the sequence is edited to flash the images up on the screen is almost sublimable and those moments in the film when Danny's own face is quickly flashed on the screen with his eyes wide open staring at the camera gives me a chill every time. Another thing i noticed last night was during the scene when Jack has just been to see the woman in the Bathroom and is talking to his wife in the bedroom about Danny the conversation soon turns into an argument and Jack goes storming out of the room. Look at his face as he walks past the camera for a moment he stares straight at the camera and straight at us watching the film. I don't believe that this was a Goof during the making the film I believe that this was done to make the audience feel uneasy and it certainly worked on me.

I love all of those massive sets that were used for the film they really give you a claustrophobic feeling when you see the characters alone in the Halls and Ballrooms and the way that Kubrick's camera glides down the endless maze of hallways. I also love the way that Kubrick kept his camera often far back from the actors leaving a lot of space above there heads and not often going for very extreme close ups which along with those massive high celling sets gives you a sense of the amount of empty space in which the characters are living in this deserted hotel.

title: Diamond in the rough.
review: If you look at the entire list of films written by Stephen King, it's basically six of one, a half dozen of the other. In other words, there's not alot of variety to what he does. But when you add crucial elements to the mix, such as the genius of both Stanley Kubrick & Jack Nicholson, as well as the most imaginative, intense and disturbing attempt of King's career, you come up with an entirely new monster.  The Shining is not only Stephen King's best stuff, it's one of the best movies ever of the genre.

title: Corridors of blood and artistic creativity...
review: Stanley Kubrick's "The Shining", tries to create the psychology that its main character lives in. Empty floors, empty corridors and a mind full of anger and sadistic thoughts. All of this may be a dream, but it's not a dream we don't live in. It's about feelings that don't come out everyday, but lives on people's mind. And Kubrick is the master of creating feelings with images, and that's the hardest thing for a movie maker...

title: Try watching this movie at the place that they filmed it at.
review:
I still remember the night that I saw this amazing film when I was 12 yrs. old. I was at the Timberline Lodge, where they had filmed the outside shots of the hotel. It was in a dark room with all of the kids in my ski camp with me. Let me tell you, it was one of the scariest and lasting movies I have ever seen.

The twins and the man in the costume serving the other man. I bet you will always remember these scenes until you die. I know I will. It scares me writing this review.

The real mastermind behind this film is the late and great Stanley Kubrick. He is the greatest director this world has ever known, and this may be his greatest masterpiece in my mind. Being the master of music that he is, he made every scene terrifying because of the music. Even when nothing is going on the movie is terrifying because of the music.

Forget about the excorcist and blair witch. If you really want to be frightened, see this film.

title: An interesting comparision to the book
review:
Stanley Kubrick's film version of THE SHINING becomes much clearer and more interesting after you've read King's novel. Many people tend to disparage either one in favor of the other, but both novel and movie have individual merits and are ultimately about entirely different themes.

In the novel, King examines a flawed but decent man (Jack Torrance) who becomes the victim of a rapacious hotel with a mind of its own that wants to devour him and his family. Jack fights long and hard against the power of the Overlook Hotel, but the hotel overpowers him and eventually fully possesses him. King shows basic optimism in humanity when he lets Jack's remaining human personality poke through during his furious final rampage and allow his son Danny to escape. The Hotel dies an incerinating death as Danny, his mother, and the helpful Hallorann escape to a new life.

No such optimism for Stanley Kubrick. Jack Torrance begins as a violent, slightly insane man who has managed to wear a mask of decency for a few years. The Hotel tempts Jack to remove that mask with its endless luxurious space, opulance, and promise of the immortality that has always alluded him in his writing. When Jack goes berszerk at the end, it really IS Jack in control, not the spirit of the Overlook wearing his shape. There is no humanity to appeal to in Jack (indeed, there never was to begin with), and Danny and his mother can only hope to escape him through their own wits.

As a film, THE SHINING is a frightfully cold tale of humanity stripped bare, and Kubrick purposely distances the story from the emotional background of King's novel, which is a tale of temptation of the human spirit and its purgation. King's novel is freeing, symbolized in the exploding Overlook Hotel, while Kubrick's film is a prison, symbolized by the hedge maze that becomes Jack's demise. It's no wonder that King dislike the movie version so strongly, but both renditions are worthy of praise, and the comparison between them further emphasizes their individual strengths.

title: spooky ghost story
review: Again I am too late to provide any new insight for a film, with it allready having been commented on 80 times on IMDb, but the only new thing I can add is give this film time to get going.  Yes, the beginning is a bit talky, but it didnt bother me cuz it was pretty interesting.  And thats basically what will make this work for you, if you find the hotel and its history intriguing or not.  I was very drawn to the story because of the huge scale, like the BIG hotel, the looong running time, the climax that took about 45 minutes.  It will all depend on what grabs you the most.  There's plenty of memorable moments; redrum, all work and no play makes Jack a dull boy, the creepy twin girls, bloody elevators, heeeeres Johnny!, and that yucky old lady in the bathtub...ewwww.  The finale is really drawn out and takes a while to unfold, but it just makes more time for spookiness.  I mean when Duvall is running through the hotel and keeps encountering twisted image after twisted image, coupled with that chilling music, I was freaked.  I'd also have to say this will take multiple viewings before everything makes sense (I had to explain a lot when my girlfriend watched it for the first time), with some of the characters not clearly defined enough.  Like I'm assuming that bartender was one Nicholson knew from his drinking days.  And for those who think this is boring, just read the book and tell me whats better.  Kings novel is even moooore blah blah blah, with the ending here much better.  Jacks and Kubricks best.

title: Too bad Kubrick didn't do more horror.
review: I am a huge Stephen King fan and am almost always disappointed with the films made from his novels.  "The Shining" is an extraordinary exception. Kubrick's interpretation and embellishment of the novel not only improve the tale, but make it what, in my opinion, is the scariest motion picture ever made.  Never before or since has a movie used general eerieness and fear of the unknown so stirringly (with the possible exception of the up and coming "The Blair Witch Project" which I cannot wait to see).  "The Shining" has an escalating menace to it that begins even as the credits roll and doesn't let up until the screen fades to black at the end.  Danny's vision of the twin Grady girls in the hallway is undoubtedly one of the most chilling scenes ever filmed and Jack and Delbert's conversation in the Men's room is, to me, Kubrick's finest work as a director.  Truly haunting.

title: Kubrick does it again.
review: The odd thing about Stanley Kubrick is that he can make a film exactly like the book it's based on (A Clockwork Orange, another favorite of mine) but he can also make a film that goes completely away from the book. The Shining was not only the first Stephen King movie I had ever seen, it was the first horror film I had ever seen. And thus far, it is the only horror film on the same level of scariness as the Exorcist and Psycho that I know of. Two names make this a great film. Any true movie fan should know these names. Kubrick and Nicholson. Let's start with Nicholson, shall we? Jack Nicholson is, simply put, the best actor ever. He portrays Jack Torrence better than anyone else ever could. Well, that was simple. OK, now let's move on to Stanley Kubrick, shall we? His vision of the future in A Clockwork Orange and his vision of outer space in 2001: A Space Oddessy are without rival, as is his vision of schizophrenia, alcoholism, parenthood, and insanity in the Shining. Well, maybe they're rivaled by Psycho and the Exorcist. But that's it. This film is a must-see for any horror movie junkie. But if you want Kubrick at his best, I suggest A Clockwork Orange. But that's just my opinion.

title: The Only Movie That Genuinely Scares Me
review:
What can I add to the many other comments on this film? Just that there are many horror films that utilize all the standard tricks and cinematic cliches to make you jump or build up suspense, but this is the only movie (The Exorcist included) that genuinely scares me and causes pause when I turn off the lights. I had not read Stephen King's book before I saw this in the theater during it's original 1980 release-- I have since and now view them as two totally different works that stand apart and individually. Kubrick understands how to penetrate the psyche to create a forboding, almost unbearable sense of something horrible lying in wait for you just around the next corner that you (almost) never quite see. The twin girls at the end of the hallway scare the bejesus out of me in a way that Freddy Kruger never could. Not even close. The Overlook's immensity and isolation leave the viewer feeling as trapped and vulnerable as the characters.

The DVD version of this film includes Vivian Kubrick's (Stanley's daughter) documentary on the making of the film. It's fascinating to watch Jack Nicholson clowning and joking around and greeting people as he walks from his dressing room to the bedroom set. While others go about their business he suddenly changes, clothes himself in his character, and gives the prop axe a furious and enthusiastic swing, shouting "Axe murderer, kill!" You also get to see Stanley Kubrick berating Shelley Duvall on set, "We're f*****g killing ourselves out here and you've gotta be ready! ...Should we play mood music?" Great stuff for any fan of movie making.

title: I fell in love with it
review: On October 31st, 1998, I witnessed what would be the greatest horror movie in movie history. The Shining came into my life, as I instantly fell in love to the movie known as The Shining. I loved the fact that they were alone in the Overlook Hotel. The movie had everything a horror movie should have: A killer chasing them, a haunted lodge with ghosts roaming around the rooms. Stanley Kubrick was a genius. Jack Nicholson really made the movie great. But Stephen King is the real mastermind.

title: The best horror film ever made
review:
Take a hotel with a gruesome past. Add a well-meaning caretaker there to spend a nice winter with his wife and child, and mix in a masterful filmmaker and a superb story teller (Kubrick and King), and you've got Stanley Kubrick's 1980 classic horror film, The Shining.
